item.description: == Links [cols=“1a,1a”, options=“header”] |=== | ASCII Format | Rendered | https://asciidoctor.org - automatic! | https://asciidoctor.org - automatic! | https://asciidoctor.org[Asciidoctor] | https://asciidoctor.org[Asciidoctor] |=== ASCII Format https://github.com/asciidoctor[Asciidoctor @ GitHub]

== Recursive list ls -R ls -l -R Using find command find . -print find . -ls Using du command du -a . du -a /path/to/search/ | more == Copy without hidden folder rsync -a --exclude='.*' /source/ /destination === Prevent deleting destination files that match a pattern rsync -avrc --delete --exclude somedir source destination rsync ... --filter 'protect /remote-directory-to-keep/' ... rsync ... --filter='P my-specific-logfile.log' exclude all log files from being transferred from the source to destination, and delete all existing ones on the destination.

== Ask for user input in bash [source,json] while true; do read -p “Do you wish to continue running this?” inp case $inp in [Yy]* ) break;; [Nn]* ) exit;; * ) echo “Please answer yes or no”;; esac done echo “Do you wish to install this program?” select yn in “Yes” “No”; do case $yn in Yes ) make install; break;; No ) exit;; esac done echo -n “Is this a good question (y/n)?

== HMAC Generator Snippet This is a sample code snippet for HMAC generation. In case you want to call an API that is protected using HMAC, below snippet can be used to do the same. Few HMAC providers might have slightly different algorithms, so please make sure the one you are using matches the outline below. [source,json] var hmacApplicationUuid = postman.getEnvironmentVariable(“hmacApplicationUuid”) console.log(hmacApplicationUuid) var hmacSecretKey = postman.getEnvironmentVariable(“hmacApplicationKey”) console.log(hmacSecretKey) var targerApiUrl = request.

== Newman Newman is the commandline equivalent of postman gui [source,json] sudo npm install -g newman; cd postman-snippets; ./run_workflows.sh json envs/env.postman_environment.json Iterate through your postman scripts #!/usr/bin/env bash ENVIRONMENT=envs/env.postman_environment.json REPORT_TYPE=html FLIP_POLICIES_BACK_TO_CORE=false if [ -n “$1” ]; then REPORT_TYPE=$1 fi if [ -n “$2” ]; then ENVIRONMENT=$2 fi if [ -d reports ]; then rm -r reports fi mkdir -p reports rm reports/postman.log 2> /dev/null for file in workflow-collections/*.json; do WORKFLOW=$(echo $file | sed -e “s/^workflow-collections\//report-/” -e “s/.
== Postman Snippets include::loop-request.adoc include::skip-request.adoc include::hmac-generator.adoc include::topt-verifier.adoc include::symmetric-jwt-generator.adoc

== TOTP verifier .TOTP Sessi updateOtp() function dec2hex(s) { return (s < 15.5 ? ‘0’ : “) + Math.round(s).toString(16); } function hex2dec(s) { return parseInt(s, 16); } function base32tohex(base32) { var base32chars = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ234567"; var bits = ""; var hex = ""; for (var i = 0; i < base32.length; i++) { var val = base32chars.indexOf(base32.charAt(i).toUpperCase()); bits += leftpad(val.toString(2), 5, '0'); } for (var j = 0; j+4 <= bits.
Handy techniques to deal with Java
Handy techniques to deal with linux

Secure copy protocol(SCP) allows files to be copied between machines/servers in a secure way. Usage scp <source-specification> <destination-specification> Tip Format for a resource in remote(source or destination) is: user@machine:filename Format for file specification on local system is : filename While accessing a remote server make sure user account exists in remote destination make sure filesystem has sufficient permission to be accessed by user account

A Fast and Flexible Static Site Generator built with love by spf13 and friends in Go. Website | Forum | Chat | Documentation | Installation Guide | Twitter
Overview Hugo is a static site generator written in Go. It is optimized for speed, easy use and configurability. Hugo takes a directory with content and templates and renders them into a full HTML website. Hugo relies on Markdown files with front matter for meta data.

Purchase domain for godaddy Host site in github Configure go daddy domain to git hub page f the domain has been forwarded or automatically connected this would need to be removed if you’re going to edit the DNS manually. Here is an article on the connection wizard, if anything is on in there make sure to turn it off. https://www.godaddy.com/help/forward-a-domain-12123 A record- Host: @

item.title: 1. Cheatsheet
item.description: Table 1. Configuration Command Usage git config --list See all the global variables that has been set git config --global user.name "John D" Used to track who has made changes to files in local system git config --global user.email johndoe@e.com Used to track who has made changes to files in local system git config --global core.

item.title: Branch - rename
item.description: GIT Rename branch It’s quite common we start using a temporary name for a feature branch we are working on, and we have to rename the branch to something more meaningful as our work progresses. In case, the git branch is still in local and has not been pushed to remote, below command can be used to rename the branch locally Rename branch locally git branch -m old_branch new_branch

item.title: Certificate Key Matcher
item.description: When you are dealing with lots of different certificates it can be easy to lose track of which certificate goes with which private key or which CSR was used to generate which certificate. The Certificate Key Matcher simply compares an md5 hash of the private key modulus, the certificate modulus, or the CSR modulus and tells you whether they match or not. You can check whether a certificate matches private key, or a CSR matches a certificate on your own computer by using the OpenSSL commands below:

item.title: Cherry pick
item.description: GIT cherry pick Cherry picking in git means to choose a commit from one branch and apply it onto another. This is in contrast with other ways such as merge and rebase which normally applies many commits onto a another branch. How to cherry pick? Make sure you are on the branch you want apply the commit to. `git checkout master` Cherry pick a specific commit feature you need from list of commits

item.title: GIT - Create feature branch
item.description: I am currently on dev and want to switch to a particular branch git status git checkout -b feature/my-new-feature-branch-name

item.title: GIT - Delete file
GIT - Ignore
item.description: Its pretty common that you have some temp files or output or generated or target folders/files that you do not want to commit to remote version control system. Such files can be added onto a .gitignore file in the root of the source project. Sample entries for a gitignore file is [source.rb] .project .classpath /.settings/ .settings* /target/ *.iml *.versionsBackup /.idea/

item.title: Generics
item.description: Handy techniques to deal with Java

item.title: Merge
item.description: GIT Merge Merge bugfix/feature onto master/dev Say your bug fix branch is called bugfix and you want to merge it into master: git checkout master git merge --squash bugfix git commit This will take all the commits from the bugfix branch, squash them into 1 commit and then merge it with your master branch. In case you think there are possible merge conflicts that can occur between master and bugfix but you know that bugfix branch has the correct changes

item.title: Replace certificate in keystore
item.description: keytool -list -v -keystore /opt/idam/jdk-8u40/jre/lib/security/cacerts keytool -delete -alias test-cert -keystore /opt/idam/jdk-8u40/jre/lib/security/cacerts keytool -import -trustcacerts -file /home/ubuntu/test.cert -alias test-cert -keystore /opt/idam/jdk-8u40/jre/lib/security/cacerts

item.title: Revert - Merged Commit
item.description: GIT revert merged commit Git revert a merged commit The -m option specifies the parent number. This is because a merge commit has more than one parent, and Git does not know automatically which parent was the mainline, and which parent was the branch you want to un-merge. When you view a merge commit in the output of git log, you will see its parents listed on the line that begins with Merge:

item.title: Tag - create
item.description: GIT Create Tag To create a tag on your current branch, run this: git tag <tagname> This will create a local tag with the current state of the branch you are on. When pushing to your remote repo, tags are NOT included by default. You will need to explicitly say that you want to push your tags to your remote repo: git push origin â€”tags Note This command will push all the tags in your local machine.

item.title: Tag - delete
item.description: GIT Delete Local/Remote Tag Its quite common during a release process or a tag process, you will need to retag a specific version or remove a tag that was already pushed to remote branch. To remove a tag if it has been pushed to remote repository git push --delete origin tagname If you also need to delete the local tag, use: git tag --delete tagname Dissecting what happened above Pushing a branch, tag, or other ref to a remote repository involves specifying "

item.title: ci/cd
item.description: How to use postman in CI/CD pipeline Postman is a pretty powerful rest testing tool with easy to use GUI as well as command line options. Postman scripts can be integrated into your CI/CD pipeline to ensure all the functionalities are in place as you pr;ogress through your development cycle. Sample workflow: START CI/CD ⇒ DEPLOY ⇒ RUN POSTMAN TESTS ⇒ PUBLISH RESULT ⇒ PASS/FAIL CI/CD Within Postman there are various features that are suited for a CI/CD pipeline

item.title: scp
item.description: Secure copy protocol(SCP) allows files to be copied between machines/servers in a secure way. Usage scp <source-specification> <destination-specification> Tip Format for a resource in remote(source or destination) is: user@machine:filename Format for file specification on local system is : filename While accessing a remote server make sure user account exists in remote destination make sure filesystem has sufficient permission to be accessed by user account

item.title: scp
item.description: Secure copy protocol(SCP) allows files to be copied between machines/servers in a secure way. Usage scp <source-specification> <destination-specification> Tip Format for a resource in remote(source or destination) is: user@machine:filename Format for file specification on local system is : filename While accessing a remote server make sure user account exists in remote destination make sure filesystem has sufficient permission to be accessed by user account
